Answer: Well, by American farmer, we are talking anything after 1776. Some big ones were the iron plow, McCormick Reaper, barbed wire, the tractor. However, irrigators have been extremely important in turning unfarmable land into tillable. Not to mention solving massive crop failures from unpredictable droughts. We are beginning to see the problems associated with running out of water for irrigation, a big problem that looks to get worse with time. Imagine if we lose the ability to farm the entire Central Valley.

Answer: The following are horridly short abridged descriptions of some of my favorite philosophical thoughts. Additionally, not all of them fall neatly within a 200 year spectrum. Please forgive any inaccuracies made through the abbreviation efforts, or discrepancies with the time period restriction given.1: Solipsism (Or Why we Might be Living in the Matrix)Whatâ€™s to say that we donâ€™t actually live in the matrix, dreaming up this fake imaginary world we live in? Or even worse, that we even have a body? What if weâ€™re each just a brain in a jar with a USB port pushed into the brain stem to make us tThe following are horridly short abridged descriptions of some of my favorite philosophical thoughts. Additionally, not all of them fall neatly within a 200 year spectrum. Please forgive any inaccuracies made through the abbreviation efforts, or discrepancies with the time period restriction given.1: Solipsism (Or Why we Might be Living in the Matrix)Whatâ€™s to say that we donâ€™t actually live in the matrix, dreaming up this fake imaginary world we live in? Or even worse, that we even have a body? What if weâ€™re each just a brain in a jar with a USB port pushed into the brain stem to make us t2: The Ship of Theseus Paradox (Or Grandfather Ax)Suppose I took something, like my car, and replaced a broken part. Is it still my car? What if I replaced more parts? Or every single part? Is it still my car then? What if I took all my previously discarded parts and reassembled them, placing it next to this new car? Which one is â€œmy carâ€? Also, what about people? My cells are replaced constantly. Am I the same person I was yesterday? Or five years ago?3: The Trolley ProblemSuppose there was a trolley out of control, on course to run over ten people. But I can pull a lever to redirect the trolley so that it runs over only4: The Prisoners DilemmaSo, suppose we have two prisoners who are refusing to cooperate, and we need to figure out which oneâ€™s guilty. We tell them both that if they rat the other out and the other keeps quiet, then the one who squeals gets off scot-free. However, if they both start pointing fingers, they both get an equal (and harsh) sentence. Likewise, if they both refuse to blame their partner in crime, they both get a light sentence. Now, while being cooperative seems like the most reasonable idea for both parties, both will inevitably weigh their options and elect to rat the other out, out of fear of taking the fall alone. This applies to the real world, too. (e.g, the arms race, expensive presidential campaigns, advertising, etc)5: The Experience MachineSo we generally think that things that gives us pleasure are good. But what if weâ€™re put into a box, or plugged into a machine, that basically gave us perfect pleasure, 100%, perfectly optimized, 24/7 for the rest of our lives? Would that really be a good thing? Is there more to life than just feeling good about things?6: Moral RelativismIs there any one correct way to determine what is right and wrong in the world? It seems like every society and culture has its own ways of determining right and wrong. Granted, some of those ways are deemed pretty horrible in hindsight, but still. Is there any way to determine what this right or wrong might be? Where do we look to figure it out?7: Mary the Super-Scientist in the Black and White RoomSuppose you were Mary, a scientist who lived in a black and white room, who used a grey-scale computer and lab equipment to learn everything there ever could be learned about neurology and optics. You understood all the terminology of colors and how light interacted with the human eye. What would happen if you were released from your room into the real world to see the colors around you? Would you have â€œlearnedâ€ anything new? Are there things that cannot be learned by mere passage of information, but must instead be experienced to understand?8: The Chinese Room Thought ExperimentWhile weâ€™re on the subject of forcing people to live in rooms, imagine this: Suppose you lived in a room where, occasionally, sheets of paper with words in Mandarin Chinese printed on them would slip through a slot. You have a book that describes in perfect detail what Chinese words you should use to reply to the person on the other side of the slot, but your book doesnâ€™t describe what the Chinese words9: Our Purpose in LifeWhy are we here? What are we meant to do with the time that weâ€™re given? Are we meant to enjoy ourselves? To help other people? Or, is that just helping other people enjoy themselves? Is it nothing? Are we given no purpose at all? Is it to pass butter, perhaps? Can we ever truly find out?10: The Problem of Free WillSo atoms and molecules work in a predictable manner. If we got a strong enough computer, we could hypothetically predict with perfect accuracy all the behaviors of, say, an entire ocean. But could it really? But what about us? Human beings, after all, are made entirely from atoms and molecules. Are we predictable? Can all of our actions be predicted with perfect certainty, if we had enough computational power? Does that mean that all of our actions, down to the day we die, are set in stone? Is it even possible to predict with absolute certainty everything we do? Or, is there something more to it that prevents such computers from making these predictions?

Answer: I will give two answers: the first on more solid historical ground, and the second more speculative.First answer: Civilization had to wait for the end of the ice age, which terminated about 15,000 years ago. At that time the glaciers had piled up a lot of good topsoil at its edge, and the melting ice provided plenty of water. Agriculture was developed for the first time in human existence, at first in Turkey. Agriculture is key; it means that not everyone has to hunt and gather, but food can be farmed by specialists. That allows others to becomes tradesmen, businessmen, and physics professors.Continue ReadingI will give two answers: the first on more solid historical ground, and the second more speculative.First answer: Civilization had to wait for the end of the ice age, which terminated about 15,000 years ago. At that time the glaciers had piled up a lot of good topsoil at its edge, and the melting ice provided plenty of water. Agriculture was developed for the first time in human existence, at first in Turkey. Agriculture is key; it means that not everyone has to hunt and gather, but food can be farmed by specialists. That allows others to becomes tradesmen, businessmen, and physics professors.Do not underestimate the rapidity of technical innovation during this period. It may seem slow, but thatâ€™s because today we take bronze and iron for granted. There were likely enormous advances in farming technology, but the wooden tools and plows used did not last for archeologists to study.The question says that â€œadvanced technologyâ€ took place 500 years ago. With the rapid growth of technology, it mightSecond answer (much more speculative, perhaps even whimsical): The true advance of humans came from a human genetic mutation that took place about 3000 years ago. One of my names for it is â€œthe dissatisfaction gene.â€ This was a gene that made people unsatisfied with their present situation. Animals never developed this; they search for environments that are good enough, and then they are satisfied. House cats are prototypical. But even elephants seem to be happy when they find a place with lots of grass and water.Not humans. Those who had this gene were never happy enough with what they had, and they pushed and developed and worked hard and created an ever expanding civilization.If you too are cursed with this gene (I think I am) then it is difficult to be happy, because no matter what you achieve, you want to do more. For that reason I sometimes refer to it as the â€œOriginal Sin Gene.â€ Like the original sin of Judaism and Christianity, it dooms humans to suffering. No matter how much life improves, we want it to be better.There is a solution that I personally try. I recognize that I must continue to strive to achieve more, and this is my burden. But I also can rise above it, and look at the world, and realize how blessed I am to live in such a wonderful place. Enjoy what we have, but never stop working to make it even better.
